Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech, which is essential to democracy.
It creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions over regular citizens.
The internet is a democratic tool that empowers ordinary people, and the bill jeopardizes this.
Excessive fines will lead to overly restrictive digital services, stifling open discussions.
The bill's scope includes not just false information but also 'misleading' or 'deceptive' information, which can stifle innovation and progress.
Industry codes could lead to anti-competitive practices, disadvantaging smaller competitors.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is an overreach and could harm international relations.
The bill contradicts the News Media Bargaining Code, highlighting inconsistencies.
It undermines the democratic process by potentially categorizing political viewpoints as misinformation.
The bill threatens fundamental human rights as outlined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Notable Quotes: This bill undermines the freedom of speech that is essential to our democracy.
The internet, in my strongly held belief, is the most powerful democratic invention of humanity.
This communism branded 'all for your safety'.
By restricting this freedom, we risk stifling innovation, progress, and the exchange of ideas.
The bill threatens these fundamental rights and disregards the diverse perspectives and beliefs of ordinary Australians.
